questions.stem: In horses, “colic” is BEST defined as:

options.label: A
options.text: A specific disease of the small intestine

options.label: B
options.text: Any clinical syndrome of abdominal pain, most commonly from gastrointestinal disorders

options.label: C
options.text: A respiratory syndrome associated with abdominal distension

options.label: D
options.text: A neuromuscular disorder causing spasms of the flank muscles

questions.explanation: Colic refers to a clinical syndrome of abdominal pain in horses, most often due to gastrointestinal disorders. It is not a specific single disease (A), nor a primary respiratory (C) or neuromuscular (D) disorder.

questions.stem: Which of the following statements about colic is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a single, well‑defined disease with uniform pathology

options.label: B
options.text: It is a clinical sign that can arise from many different lesions and severities

options.label: D
options.text: It is always self‑limiting and never life‑threatening

questions.explanation: Colic is a sign resulting from a wide variety of underlying lesions and can range from mild to life‑threatening. It is not a uniform disease entity (A), and it can affect horses of many ages (C) with potentially fatal outcomes (D).

questions.stem: Common gastrointestinal causes of colic in horses include:

options.label: A
options.text: Gas, impaction, inflammation, displacement, or strangulation

questions.explanation: Common GI causes include gas, impaction, inflammation, displacement, and strangulation of intestinal segments. Limiting it to gastric ulcers (B) or non‑GI systems (C, D) is inaccurate.

questions.stem: Which general pathophysiologic mechanism can lead to colic in horses?

options.label: B
options.text: Interruption of intestinal motility, obstruction, inflammation, or torsion/volvulus

questions.explanation: Interruption of intestinal motility, physical obstruction, inflammation, and torsion/volvulus are major pathophysiologic mechanisms of colic. Hyperinsulinemia (A), primary cardiac disease (C), or isolated hypocalcemia (D) may cause other problems but are not the key mechanisms highlighted.

questions.stem: Which of the following is NOT listed as a key pathophysiologic category contributing to colic?

options.label: D
options.text: Primary neoplasia of the spleen only

questions.explanation: The slide lists obstruction, impaction of the large intestine, inflammation of the GI tract, interruption of motility, torsion/volvulus/displacement, and secondary systemic effects. Primary splenic neoplasia alone (D) is not listed as a core category.

questions.stem: Regarding signalment, which statement about colic is MOST accurate?

options.label: B
options.text: Colic can affect horses of any age, breed, or sex, though certain management patterns increase risk

options.label: C
options.text: Only geriatric horses are at risk

questions.explanation: Colic can occur in horses of any age, breed, or sex, though management and usage (diet, exercise, housing) strongly influence risk. Restriction to specific age groups or breeds (A, C, D) is incorrect.

questions.stem: Which management or usage factor is recognized as increasing the risk of colic?

options.label: B
options.text: Stall confinement, high‑concentrate feeding, and irregular exercise schedules

options.label: C
options.text: Minimal changes in diet over time

options.label: D
options.text: Daily access to pasture with constant water

questions.explanation: Stall confinement, high‑concentrate diets, abrupt feed changes, and inconsistent exercise increase colic risk. Consistent forage and turnout with fresh water (A, C, D) are preventive, not risk‑inducing, practices.

questions.stem: Mild clinical signs of colic may include:

options.label: A
options.text: Intermittent flank watching, reduced appetite, lying down more than usual

questions.explanation: Mild colic may show subtle signs such as intermittent flank watching, reduced appetite, and lying down more than usual. Respiratory or neurologic signs (B, C, D) are not typical for mild colic.

questions.stem: In more severe colic, changes in vital signs often include:

options.label: B
options.text: Increased heart rate, increased respiratory rate, and prolonged capillary refill time

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased respiratory rate with bounding pulses

questions.explanation: Severe colic commonly causes tachycardia, tachypnea, and prolonged capillary refill time due to pain and circulatory compromise. Bradycardia or hypothermia (A, C) are atypical, and the pattern in D does not fit.

questions.stem: Which statement about gastrointestinal sounds in colic is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: Gut sounds are always absent in all colic cases

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced or absent sounds may indicate ileus, whereas increased sounds can occur in early spasm

options.label: C
options.text: Increased gut sounds always indicate health

options.label: D
options.text: Gut sounds are not useful in assessing colic

questions.explanation: Reduced or absent GI sounds can indicate ileus, whereas early spasm may briefly increase sounds. Gut sounds are not uniformly absent (A), always normal when increased (C), nor useless (D).

questions.stem: Abdominal distension in a colic case most likely suggests:

options.label: B
options.text: Accumulation of gas or fluid within the intestines

options.label: D
options.text: Neurologic disease of the spinal cord

questions.explanation: Abdominal distension is usually due to accumulation of gas or fluid in the intestines. It is not primarily a sign of respiratory disease (A), muscle hypertrophy (C), or neurologic lesions (D).

questions.stem: Signs of systemic involvement in severe colic may include:

options.label: B
options.text: Depression, circulatory compromise, cold extremities, and endotoxemia signs

questions.explanation: Severe systemic involvement may include depression, circulatory compromise, cold extremities, prolonged CRT, and signs of endotoxemia. The other options do not reflect the systemic shock‑like state seen in serious colic.

questions.stem: Which diagnostic procedure is commonly used EARLY in the evaluation of equine colic?

options.label: A
options.text: Endoscopic examination of the lungs only

options.label: B
options.text: Thorough clinical exam including history, physical exam, rectal palpation, nasogastric intubation, ultrasonography, and bloodwork

questions.explanation: A complete colic work‑up includes history, physical exam, rectal palpation, nasogastric intubation, ultrasonography, bloodwork, and sometimes radiography. Lung endoscopy (A), brain MRI (C), or fecal flotation alone (D) do not represent a standard colic evaluation.

questions.stem: Rectal palpation in colic cases is primarily used to:

options.label: B
options.text: Evaluate portions of the gastrointestinal tract for distension, displacement, or impaction

questions.explanation: Rectal palpation allows assessment of accessible GI segments for distension, displacement, or impaction. It is unrelated to laryngeal function (A), direct blood pressure measurement (C), or laminitis diagnosis (D).

questions.stem: Nasogastric intubation in a colic work‑up is important for:

options.label: B
options.text: Decompression of the stomach and assessing for gastric reflux

questions.explanation: Nasogastric intubation is essential to decompress the stomach, relieve reflux, and help prevent gastric rupture, and to assess for excessive reflux. It is not mainly for sedative administration (A) or respiratory/urinary evaluation (C, D).

questions.stem: Which of the following is NOT a common gastrointestinal differential diagnosis for equine colic?
questions.explanation: Large colon or cecal impactions, colon displacements/torsions, and small intestinal obstruction/strangulation are key GI causes; primary skin infection (D) is not a GI colic differential. Thus, D is the correct “NOT” option.

questions.stem: Which of the following is a NON‑gastrointestinal cause that can mimic colic?
questions.explanation: Non‑GI conditions such as uterine torsion or kidney stones can mimic colic pain. Laryngeal hemiplegia (B), uveitis (C), or laminitis (D) may cause other signs but are not the classic non‑GI colic mimics listed.

questions.stem: Supportive care in medical management of colic typically includes:

options.label: A
options.text: Analgesics, sedation, fluids, and controlled walking

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate surgical exploration for all cases

questions.explanation: Medical management commonly involves analgesics, sedation, fluid therapy, and controlled walking when appropriate. Sole stall rest (B), blanket surgery (C), or fasting without water (D) are not recommended across the board.

questions.stem: Decompression in colic management generally refers to:

options.label: B
options.text: Using a nasogastric tube to relieve gastric reflux and, in some cases, emergency intestinal decompression

options.label: D
options.text: Reducing joint effusion in the limb

questions.explanation: Decompression refers to relieving pressure, usually via nasogastric tubing to drain gastric reflux, and sometimes other emergency procedures to evacuate gas/fluid. Tracheotomy (A), lung removal (C), or limb joint drainage (D) are unrelated.

questions.stem: Specific therapy for an impaction‑type colic often involves:

options.label: A
options.text: Laxatives and fluids to soften and move the impaction

questions.explanation: Impaction colic often responds to laxatives (e.g., mineral oil, osmotic agents) and fluids to soften and move the impaction. Euthanasia (B), short antibiotic courses (C), or steroids alone (D) are not appropriate first‑line therapies.

questions.stem: Surgical intervention is MOST likely indicated in colic cases involving:

options.label: A
options.text: Simple spasmodic colic that resolves with analgesia

questions.explanation: Surgical exploration is typically indicated for displacements, torsions, and strangulating obstructions, or when medical therapy fails. Simple spasmodic or mild gas colic (A, C) can often be managed medically.

questions.stem: Ongoing monitoring of a colic patient should include:

options.label: B
options.text: Repeated exams, vital signs, gut sounds, and sometimes peritoneal fluid analysis

questions.explanation: Good management includes repeated physical exams, vital sign checks, auscultation of gut sounds, and, when indicated, peritoneal fluid analysis to monitor progression. Single exams (A) or irrelevant checks (C, D) are inadequate.

questions.stem: Which factor is LEAST likely to IMPROVE prognosis in a colic case?

options.label: B
options.text: Absence of vascular compromise or endotoxemia

questions.explanation: Development of laminitis, peritonitis, or severe endotoxemia worsens prognosis, whereas rapid intervention, absence of vascular compromise, and early recognition (A, B, D) improve it.

questions.stem: Recognized risk factors for equine colic include:

options.label: A
options.text: Sudden feed changes, low‑fiber diet, dehydration, poor dental health, stall confinement, parasite burden, and prior colic episodes

options.label: B
options.text: High‑fiber diet, ample water, and regular exercise

options.label: D
options.text: Minimal concentrate feeding and constant turnout

questions.explanation: The listed risk factors include sudden feed changes, low‑fiber diets, dehydration, poor dentition, stall confinement, parasite burden, and a history of colic. The other options (B–D) describe preventive practices.

questions.stem: Which is a common complication that can arise secondary to severe colic or its treatment?

options.label: B
options.text: Endotoxemia and shock, laminitis, peritonitis, adhesions, or intestinal strictures post‑surgery

questions.explanation: Serious colic or its treatment can lead to endotoxemia and shock, laminitis, peritonitis, and adhesions or intestinal strictures post‑surgery. Otitis, photosensitization, or chronic respiratory disease (A, C, D) are not typical.

questions.stem: Which management practice BEST helps prevent colic in horses?

options.label: A
options.text: Frequent sudden diet changes to prevent boredom

options.label: B
options.text: Providing consistent forage, avoiding sudden diet changes, ensuring constant access to fresh water, maintaining dental and parasite care, and offering regular turnout/exercise

options.label: C
options.text: Feeding large high‑concentrate meals once daily

questions.explanation: Prevention emphasizes consistent forage, avoiding sudden diet changes, constant fresh water, regular dental and parasite care, and steady turnout or exercise while avoiding excessive concentrates. The other practices (A, C, D) increase colic risk.

questions.stem: In long‑term management of a horse recovering from colic, which recommendation is MOST appropriate?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate return to full feed and intense exercise

options.label: B
options.text: Gradual return to feed and exercise with a high‑fiber diet, regular water intake, and monitoring for recurrence

options.label: C
options.text: Permanent stall rest with no diet changes

options.label: D
options.text: Elimination of forage from the diet

questions.explanation: After colic, horses should return gradually to feeding and exercise, with a high‑fiber diet, good hydration, and close monitoring for recurrence. Abrupt intense work (A), permanent strict confinement (C), or eliminating forage (D) are not appropriate.
